importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date when the administration officially confirmed there are no immediate plans for a Trump-Putin summit, signaling a shift in diplomatic strategy.
This was the date of the Thursday phone call between Trump and Putin where Trump initially proposed a quick summit within two weeks.
The call between Trump and Putin set initial expectations for a summit, which later collapsed due to lack of progress and divergent positions.
This was the date of the Rubio-Lavrov phone call, which indicated limited progress and differing expectations on ending the Ukraine conflict.
Trump announced he would notify the public about next steps, indicating ongoing diplomatic evaluation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The originally proposed timeline for a Trump-Putin summit, which has now been abandoned.

keyTakeAways: The Trump administration has officially canceled plans for an immediate summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov had a phone call with no agreement on ending the war or advancing a summit.
The Kremlin rejected the idea of freezing the conflict, which was proposed by Trump after meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.
Ukrainian President Zelensky attributes reduced Russian diplomatic interest to the U.S. refusal to provide Ukraine with long-range Tomahawk missiles.
Lavrov is seen as a figurehead with limited influence on major Russian decisions, making high-level bilateral meetings with him less effective.
The White House maintains that President Trump remains committed to diplomatic peace in Ukraine, even if a direct summit with Putin is delayed.
Future meetings between Rubio and Lavrov may occur at an ASEAN-led multilateral event in Malaysia.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is the central figure in the article, with his stated desire to hold a quick summit with Putin driving the narrative and prompting diplomatic shifts.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin is the counterpart to Trump in the proposed summit, and his position on the war and diplomacy directly affects the feasibility of a meeting.

namedEntities.name: Marco Rubio
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rubio was expected to meet with Lavrov to lay groundwork for a Trump-Putin summit, and his lack of confidence in progress signals the collapse of that plan.

namedEntities.name: Sergey Lavrov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lavrov's limited influence and maximalist stance on Ukraine show why the summit is no longer seen as viable.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelensky
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zelensky's assertion that Russian diplomacy has cooled due to lack of U.S. missile support highlights a key geopolitical factor in peace negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Dmitry Peskov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Peskov defended the Kremlin's position on no postponement of a summit, adding a counterpoint to U.S. diplomatic withdrawal.

namedEntities.name: Anna Kelly
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She communicates the administration's stance that Trump remains committed to peace, despite the summit delay.

namedEntities.name: Mark Rutte
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is scheduled to meet Rutte, showing continued high-level diplomatic engagement with Western allies.

namedEntities.name: ASEAN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: ASEAN is proposed as a potential venue for future Rubio-Lavrov meetings, indicating a shift to multilateral diplomacy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump's hopes for a swift summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin have been scrapped, with the White House now stating there are no immediate plans for such a meeting. This reversal follows a previous announcement that a summit would take place within two weeks after a phone call between the two leaders. Diplomatic efforts involving U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov failed to produce meaningful progress, with both sides expressing divergent views on ending the war in Ukraine. The Kremlin rejected the proposal to freeze the conflict, which Trump had previously supported, and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky cited the U.S. refusal to provide long-range missiles as a key reason Russia has become less interested in diplomacy. Experts note that Lavrov lacks real influence over Russian policy, making high-level bilateral talks ineffective. The administration now sees no need for a standalone meeting between Rubio and Lavrov, and instead considers future discussions at multilateral events like ASEAN’s upcoming meeting in Malaysia. Despite the delay, the White House reaffirms Trump’s ongoing commitment to achieving peace in Ukraine.
title: Trump’s hopes for quick second summit with Putin have stalled out
